MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - County Tipperary Estate Acquisition.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture if he will request the Land Commission to acquire the Cleary estate, Thomastown, Golden, County Tipperary, for the relief of congestion among smallholders in the area; and if he will receive a deputation in the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Gibbons) James Gibbons
Speaker.P: The Land Commission recently inspected the property referred to with a view to determining whether acquisition proceedings should be instituted. The report furnished is now being studied and it is expected that a decision will be made known shortly.
As the determination of the actual lands to be acquired is reserved by law to the Lay Commissioners, no useful purpose would be served if I were to receive a deputation in this matter.

asked the Minister for Industry, Commerce and Energy if a compulsory purchase order has ever been used for the acquisition of land by the IDA; and if the IDA are contemplating using compulsory purchase orders in County Kerry or West Limerick.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Industry, Commerce and Energy (Mr. O'Malley) Desmond J. O'Malley
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Industry, Commerce and Energy (Mr. O'Malley)
Speaker.P: Compulsory purchase powers have been used by the Industrial Development Authority on three occasions in the past to acquire property at Ringaskiddy, County Cork and at Aughinish Island, County Limerick.

The authority are using their powers of compulsory purchase at present to acquire 197 acres of land in the Tarbert/Ballylongford area of County Kerry. Formal notification (“Notices to Treat”) in the matter were issued on 5 May 1978 to the landowners concerned. The authority are not at present contemplating the use of a compulsory purchase order in respect of any lands in West Limerick.

asked the Minister for the Environment if he will allocate funds for the erection of a scheme of houses for old people at Dungarvan, County Waterford, the plans for which have been submitted to his Department.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Barrett) Minister for the Environment (Mr. Barrett)

asked the Minister for the Environment if he will make a grant available for the erection of an indoor heated swimming poor in Dungarvan, County Waterford.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Barrett) Minister for the Environment (Mr. Barrett)
Speaker.P: The only such proposal of which I am aware is one by Dungarvan Urban District Council which was approved in principle some years ago by my Department. The urban council have now informed my Department that they intend to reactivate this project.

The financial assistance from my Department for swimming pools provided by local authorities takes the form of subsidy at the rate of 50 per cent of the annual loan charges on loans raised for the purpose. Any such loan proposal which may be submitted by Dungarvan Urban District Council will be considered in the light of the capital available for swimming pools generally and the demands on this capital.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - County Tipperary School Transport.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education when and why the school bus service on the Poulmucka route to Rathkeevan national school, Clonmel, County Tipperary, was withdrawn; and if, in view of the hardship caused to the children concerned, he will have it restored.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. Wilson) John P. Wilson
Speaker.P: As the number of eligible children entitled to free transport to Rathkeevan national school fell below the required minimum, the Department had no option but to withdraw this service at Easter 1978. There is not a sufficient number of such eligible children in the locality concerned at present to warrant the restoration of the service.

asked the Minister for Education when and why the school bus service was withdrawn from a route serving Grange national school, Clonmel, County Tipperary; and if he will have full service restored on all routes to this school without delay.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. Wilson) John P. Wilson
Speaker.P: The service to Grange national school was withdrawn at Easter 1978 because the number of eligible children availing themselves of the service for the two consecutive terms ended Easter 1978 had fallen below the minimum number required to maintain the service. It is understood that the same position obtains during the current school term. The service may be restored only from a date from which the relevant conditions are fulfilled. For this purpose a minimum of ten eligible children availing themselves of the service on a regular basis will be required.
asked the Minister for Education if he will take steps to guarantee a full and adequate school bus service to Lisronagh national school, Clonmel, County Tipperary.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. Wilson) John P. Wilson
Speaker.P: A free school transport service may be continued to any school only in accordance with the relevant regulations.

If the number of eligible children in the case of Lisronagh national school is below the required minimum for two consecutive terms in the period ending Summer 1978 it will be necessary to discontinue the service after the closing of the school for the summer holidays.

asked the Minister for Education the routes from which school buses have been withdrawn or on which services have been curtailed in South Tipperary since 5 July 1977; and the names of the schools concerned in each case, together with the reasons.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. Wilson) John P. Wilson
Speaker.P: Services were withdrawn in the following cases in South Tipperary since 5 July 1977: (1) the service to Grange national school operating from the Kilnamuck, Knockeen, Rathogally, Burgessland and Rathwater areas; (2) the service to Rathkeevan national school operating from the Poulnamucka, Graigue and Donegal areas; (3) the service to Tipperary Parochial Church of Ireland national school which operated from Annacarty.
The service was withdrawn in each case because the numbers of eligible children being conveyed fell below the minimum required for retention of the service.
